text:
Revoluci√≥n en el reciclaje: descomponen pl√°stico con la humedad del aire
"Nuestro estudio ofrece una soluci√≥n sostenible y eficiente a uno de los desaf√≠os ambientales m√°s acuciantes del mundo: los residuos pl√°sticos", explica uno de los cient√≠ficos a cargo del trabajo.
Aprovechando la humedad del aire, qu√≠micos de la Universidad Northwestern han desarrollado un nuevo m√©todo sencillo para descomponer los residuos pl√°sticos, indica un nuevo descubrimiento. Este proceso, no t√≥xico, ecol√≥gico y sin disolventes, utiliza primero un catalizador econ√≥mico para romper los enlaces del tereftalato de polietileno (PET), el pl√°stico m√°s com√∫n de la familia del poli√©ster. Posteriormente, los investigadores simplemente exponen los fragmentos rotos al aire ambiente. Aprovechando las trazas de humedad del aire, el PET descompuesto se convierte en mon√≥meros, los componentes esenciales de los pl√°sticos. A partir de ah√≠, los investigadores prev√©n que los mon√≥meros podr√≠an reciclarse en nuevos productos de PET u otros materiales m√°s valiosos.
M√°s segura, limpia, econ√≥mica y sostenible que los m√©todos actuales de reciclaje de pl√°stico, la nueva t√©cnica, publicada en la revista Green Chemistry, ofrece un camino prometedor hacia la creaci√≥n de una econom√≠a circular para los pl√°sticos, seg√∫n destaca la universidad en un comunicado.
"Estados Unidos es el mayor contaminante de pl√°stico per c√°pita, y solo reciclamos el 5% de esos pl√°sticos", afirm√≥ Yosi Kratish, de Northwestern, coautor del estudio. Existe una necesidad imperiosa de mejores tecnolog√≠as que puedan procesar diferentes tipos de residuos pl√°sticos. La mayor√≠a de las tecnolog√≠as disponibles actualmente funden botellas de pl√°stico y las reciclan para obtener productos de menor calidad. Lo especialmente emocionante de nuestra investigaci√≥n es que aprovechamos la humedad del aire para descomponer los pl√°sticos, logrando un proceso excepcionalmente limpio y selectivo. Al recuperar los mon√≥meros, que son los componentes b√°sicos del PET, podemos reciclarlos o incluso supra-reciclarlos para obtener materiales m√°s valiosos.
"Nuestro estudio ofrece una soluci√≥n sostenible y eficiente a uno de los desaf√≠os ambientales m√°s acuciantes del mundo: los residuos pl√°sticos", afirm√≥ Naveen Malik, primer autor del estudio. "A diferencia de los m√©todos de reciclaje tradicionales, que a menudo producen subproductos nocivos como sales residuales y requieren un consumo considerable de energ√≠a o productos qu√≠micos, nuestro enfoque utiliza un proceso sin disolventes que se basa en la humedad residual del aire ambiente. Esto lo hace no solo respetuoso con el medio ambiente, sino tambi√©n muy pr√°ctico para aplicaciones pr√°cticas".
El problema del pl√°stico
Com√∫nmente utilizado en envases de alimentos y botellas de bebidas, el PET representa el 12 % del total de pl√°sticos utilizados a nivel mundial. Debido a su dificultad para descomponerse, el PET contribuye significativamente a la contaminaci√≥n pl√°stica. Tras su uso, termina en vertederos o, con el tiempo, se degrada en diminutos micropl√°sticos o nanopl√°sticos, que a menudo acaban en aguas residuales y cursos de agua.
Encontrar nuevas formas de reciclar el pl√°stico es un tema candente en la investigaci√≥n. Sin embargo, los m√©todos actuales para descomponer los pl√°sticos requieren condiciones rigurosas, como temperaturas extremadamente altas, un alto consumo de energ√≠a y disolventes, que generan subproductos t√≥xicos. Los catalizadores utilizados en estas reacciones suelen ser caros (como el platino y el paladio) o t√≥xicos, lo que genera residuos a√∫n m√°s da√±inos. Tras la reacci√≥n, los investigadores deben separar los materiales reciclados de los disolventes, un proceso que puede requerir mucho tiempo y energ√≠a.
Sin disolventes
En trabajos anteriores, el grupo de Marks en Northwestern fue el primero en desarrollar procesos catal√≠ticos que no requieren disolventes. En el nuevo estudio, el equipo ide√≥ un proceso sin disolventes.
"Usar disolventes tiene muchas desventajas", afirm√≥ Kratish. "Pueden ser caros y hay que calentarlos a altas temperaturas. Despu√©s de la reacci√≥n, se obtiene una mezcla de materiales que hay que clasificar para recuperar los mon√≥meros. En lugar de usar disolventes, utilizamos vapor de agua del aire. Es una forma mucho m√°s elegante de abordar los problemas del reciclaje de pl√°stico".

title: Medal of Honor Monday: Air Force Chief Master Sgt. Richard Etchberger > U.S. Department of Defense > Story
text:
Many military men and women do heroic things that they can't get credit for because they're involved in classified missions. For Air Force Chief Master Sgt. Richard Loy Etchberger, he finally did get credit in the form of the Medal of Honor 42 years after he lost his life saving others during the Vietnam War.
Air Force Chief Master Sgt. Richard L. Etchberger Medal of Honor recipient Air Force Chief Master Sgt. Richard L. Etchberger poses for a photo at Udorn Air Base, Thailand. It was taken shortly before his death in March 1968 during a battle at a secret U.S. radar site on a mountain peak in Laos. Share: √ó Share Copy Link Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Download: Full Size ( 1.93 MB ) Photo By: Courtesy photo VIRIN: 680201-O-D0439-001
Etchberger was born March 5, 1933, in Hamburg, Pennsylvania, to Donald and Kathryn Etchberger. He had an older brother named Robert.
When their father lost his job after the Pearl Harbor attacks, both boys started to work odd jobs to help with finances. Eventually, the family moved to nearby Minersville, Pennsylvania, so his dad could find more work. There, Etchberger became a star basketball player and excelled in academics. His brother said it helped that he had a photographic memory.
"When he would go upstairs to study, he would be done in 10 minutes. Then, he was back downstairs doing whatever he wanted. That used to infuriate me because I couldn't learn my lessons that quickly," Robert Etchberger said in an interview for an article on the Airmen Memorial Museum website.
After World War II ended, the family moved back to Hamburg, where Etchberger finished high school. He was the senior class president by the time he graduated in 1951.
A few weeks later, Etchberger enlisted in the Air Force. He initially wanted to be a pilot, his brother said, but due to an injury that lingered from his basketball days, he washed out of aviation school. Instead, he was trained as a radio operator and came to be known to be an electronics whiz.
Air Force Chief Master Sgt. Richard L. Etchberger A photo of Air Force Chief Master Sgt. Richard L. Etchberger taken in an unspecified location in 1968. Share: √ó Share Copy Link Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Download: Full Size ( 573.44 KB ) Photo By: Air Force VIRIN: 110906-F-XN622-009C
A few years into his service, Etchberger met Catherine Vaccaria while on assignment in Utah. The pair married in 1956, with Etchberger taking on the role of stepfather to Catherine's son, Steve. By 1959, they had two more sons, Richard and Cory.
In August 1965, Etchberger and the whole family were transferred to Clark Air Base in the Philippines. Aside from his standard duties there, Etchberger was also the communications and electronics noncommissioned officer in charge of a radar control post on Hon Tree Island in Vietnam, where the U.S. was now at war.
Spotlight: Commemorating the Vietnam War
After a brief stint back in the U.S., Etchberger was assigned to the 1043rd Radar Evaluation Squadron and placed on a top-secret Air Force/CIA mission code-named Project Heavy Green. It called for Etchberger and a small team to go to a small radar station on top of a remote mountain in Laos that was being used to direct U.S. air support to North Vietnam during the early years of the war.
The mission wasn't easy to join. Etchberger and the other airmen involved needed to be released from the Air Force and hired by Lockheed Corporation to avoid giving the perception that Laos was involved with the U.S. government in the war. When the mission was over, the airmen would be welcomed back into the Air Force.
A view of the ridgeline of Phou Pha Thi mountain and the Combat Sky Spot radar site known as Lima Site 85. Window View A view of the ridgeline of Phou Pha Thi mountain and the Combat Sky Spot radar site known as Lima Site 85. Share: √ó Share Copy Link Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Download: Full Size ( 1.45 MB ) Photo By: Air Force VIRIN: 110804-F-XN622-001C
In early 1968, Etchberger and his team made it to the radar station, which was called Lima Site 85. From that mountainous jungle perch, which was only 12 miles from North Vietnam, about 40 airmen controlled hundreds of air strikes into enemy territory during the 1968 Rolling Thunder campaign.
The North Vietnamese knew the value of the site, so they made many attempts to take it out. None were successful until March 10, 1968, when they began to attack the site with heavy artillery. By nightfall, Etchberger and his off-duty team realized their sleeping quarters were vulnerable to the shelling, so they hid with their guns and survival radios on a ledge partially protected by a rocky overhang for the rest of the night.
Early the next morning, enemy commandos scaled the cliff the compound was on, killing 11 of the 19 Americans working at the site. While Etchberger's team was initially spared, it didn't take long for the enemy to find them and start attacking, killing two airmen and seriously injuring two others.
Since Etchberger was a radar technician, he didn't have any formal combat training. But that didn't stop him from picking up arms and defending their position. For hours, Etchberger single-handedly held off the enemy with an M-16 rifle, all while calling for air rescue and directing air strikes that were practically right on top of him.
Once rescuers arrived, Etchberger risked his own life several times, running through heavy fire to put three of his wounded comrades into rescue slings hanging from the hovering rescue helicopter. But when he finally climbed into the sling himself and was lifted to the chopper, he was hit by a burst of gunfire. Etchberger survived the initial helicopter flight, but he died before he could be transported for further medical treatment.
Etchberger, who had turned 35 the week prior, gave his own life to save the lives of his remaining crew. Of the 19 men on the mountain that night, only seven made it out alive ‚Äî three of them thanks to Etchberger's actions.
Medal Ceremony Chief Master Sgt. Richard Etchberger‚Äôs wife, Catherine, receives his posthumous Air Force Cross from Air Force Chief of Staff Gen. John McConnell at a private Pentagon ceremony in 1969. Catherine Etchberger was sworn to secrecy about the mission that led to her husband‚Äôs death because it was classified. His Air Force Cross did not become public knowledge until 1998. Share: √ó Share Copy Link Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Download: Full Size ( 962.56 KB ) Photo By: Air Force VIRIN: 110906-F-XN622-010C
The slain airman's body was returned to the U.S. and buried in St. Johns Cemetery in his hometown.
Since details of the mission were classified, Etchberger was secretly awarded the Air Force Cross. Nine months after the mission, his wife, who accepted the honor on his behalf, was told the real story of what happened to her husband; however, she was sworn to secrecy. Etchberger's sons didn't even learn the truth until the late 1980's when the details were finally declassified.
Once his actions were no longer a secret, they remained relatively hidden in the past until the early 2000's. That's when Air Force Master Sgt. Robert Dilley read about Etchberger's heroism and thought more should be done to honor him. Dilley wrote his local congressman, and, together, they began a years-long movement to have Etchberger recognized with the Medal of Honor.
That dream came to fruition on Sept. 21, 2010, when Etchberger's sons received the nation's highest medal for valor in their father's name from President Barack Obama during a White House ceremony.
Medal Ceremony President Barack Obama presents the Medal of Honor posthumously to the sons of Air Force Chief Master Sgt. Richard L. Etchberger during a ceremony in the East Room of the White House, Sept. 21, 2010. From left: Steve Wilson, Corey Etchberger and Richard Etchberger. Chief Master Sgt. Richard Etchberger received the Medal of Honor for his heroic actions in combat in Laos on March 11, 1968, after deliberately exposing himself to enemy fire in order to place three surviving wounded comrades in rescue slings, which permitted them to be airlifted to safety. Share: √ó Share Copy Link Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Download: Full Size ( 296.96 KB ) Photo By: Pete Souza, White House VIRIN: 100921-O-D0439-027C
Etchberger's wife, Catherine, was also recognized for her own personal sacrifice in keeping the secret ‚Äî something she never told anyone, even upon her death in 1994.
"She kept that promise, to her husband and her country, all those years, not even telling her own sons," Obama said. "So, today is also a tribute to Catherine Etchberger and a reminder of the extraordinary sacrifices that our military spouses make on behalf of our nation."
Etchberger's actions continue to be honored in the military today. Various Air Force bases have renamed streets and buildings for him, including Barksdale Air Force Base, which also displays his name etched in a granite monument. Etchberger's family donated his chief's uniform and various other items to a display honoring him at the Air Force Senior NCO Academy at Maxwell Air Force Base, Alabama.
Bench Monument Robert Etchberger, the brother of Air Force Chief Master Sgt. Richard L. Etchberger, admires a newly unveiled bench monument in honor of his brother at the 50th anniversary memorial service of Lima Site 85 at Gunter Annex on Maxwell Air Force Base, Ala., March 12. 2018. Lima Site 85 was the location of a covert operation during the Vietnam War where about a dozen Americans went missing or lost their lives fighting the enemy, including Etchberger, who was killed during extraction. He was posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor in 2010 for his heroic actions that saved three lives that day. Share: √ó Share Copy Link Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Download: Full Size ( 1024 KB ) Photo By: Air Force Master Sgt. Stephen D. Schester VIRIN: 180312-F-AU128-0344
This article is part of a weekly series called "Medal of Honor Monday," in which we highlight one of the more than 3,500 Medal of Honor recipients who have earned the U.S. military's highest medal for valor.

text:
Tres turistas de Yellowstone condenados a c√°rcel por infringir normas en √°reas protegidas del parque. Tres visitantes del Parque Nacional de Yellowstone fueron condenados el mes pasado a penas breves de c√°rcel por delitos menores no relacionados, dijeron los fiscales federales, lo que enfatiza la necesidad de seguridad en las zonas protegidas del parque. Dos visitantes que se desviaron de senderos o caminos se√±alizados de manera clara en zonas termales del parque fueron condenados a siete d√≠as de c√°rcel cada uno, seg√∫n la fiscal√≠a del distrito de Wyoming . Un tercer visitante fue condenado a 10 d√≠as por conducir bajo los efectos del alcohol en el parque, dijeron las autoridades.
Los tres fueron condenados por violaciones de terrenos p√∫blicos ocurridas durante el oto√±o pasado, y sus condenas se dictaron pocas semanas antes de que comience la temporada alta de turismo en Yellowstone, cuya mayor parte se encuentra en Wyoming .
‚ÄúLa prioridad n√∫mero 1 es la seguridad p√∫blica , pero los recursos naturales tambi√©n son importantes en lugares como el Parque Nacional de Yellowstone ‚Äù, dijo Lori Hogan, responsable de asuntos p√∫blicos de la fiscal√≠a de Wyoming. ‚ÄúLas infracciones m√°s peligrosas, como entrar en un √°rea t√©rmica o trastocar la vida salvaje, podr√≠an llevar a penas de c√°rcel, mientras que las infracciones menores podr√≠an dar lugar a multas o advertencias‚Äù, explic√≥.
Caminar por los terrenos termales de Yellowstone puede ser extremadamente peligroso, dijeron los responsables del parque, debido a que el suelo es fr√°gil y delgado, y el agua hirviendo debajo de la superficie puede causar quemaduras graves o mortales. Hay m√°s de 24 kil√≥metros de caminos establecidos para que los turistas puedan observar los atractivos termales de Yellowstone, como g√©iseres y aguas termales . Los caminos, claramente se√±alizados, protegen tambi√©n el entorno inestable, se√±alaron las autoridades.
Instrumentan dureza legal para proteger √°reas fr√°giles y recursos naturales en Yellowstone. (Visit The USA) La zona de observaci√≥n que rodea al g√©iser Old Faithful es una de las atracciones m√°s populares del parque, y fue all√≠ donde los responsables dijeron que Angela Flaherty , de 44 a√±os, de Seattle, se desvi√≥ unos 3 metros del camino establecido y cay√≥ sobre el cono del Old Faithful . Otro visitante del parque grab√≥ sus acciones en video. Flaherty fue condenada el 19 de marzo a una pena de siete d√≠as el mes pasado y se le orden√≥ pagar 40 d√≥lares en concepto de costos judiciales obligatorios.
Yiyang Shen , de 25 a√±os, procedente de Doraville , Georgia, fue condenado el 12 de marzo a siete d√≠as de c√°rcel. Condujo fuera de un camino, aparc√≥ su veh√≠culo en una zona termal y camin√≥ por el √°rea prohibida, dijeron los fiscales. Shen da√±√≥ recursos del parque, aseguraron las autoridades. Estar√° en libertad condicional sin supervisi√≥n durante cinco a√±os ‚Äîy no podr√° visitar Yellowstone en ese tiempo‚Äî y se le orden√≥ pagar 1050 d√≥lares en multas y costos judiciales.
Douglas Wolfley , de 49 a√±os, de Fairview , Wyoming, fue condenado el 18 de marzo a 10 d√≠as de c√°rcel tras declararse culpable de conducir bajo los efectos del alcohol en Yellowstone, su tercera condena por conducir bajo los efectos de sustancias en 10 a√±os. Se le impusieron tres a√±os de libertad condicional sin supervisi√≥n , durante los cuales se le prohibir√° la entrada al parque, y se le orden√≥ pagar 3050 d√≥lares en multas y costos judiciales.
Los turistas que reciben condenas por infracciones en el parque no est√°n obligados a cumplirlas en Wyoming , dijeron funcionarios de la fiscal√≠a. Normalmente, las cumplen en una c√°rcel cercana a su lugar de residencia.
Shen dijo que hab√≠a esperado resolver el asunto con una multa , pero se√±al√≥ que respetaba la sentencia porque no hab√≠a seguido las normas locales. En su defensa, Shen indic√≥ que no sab√≠a que estaba prohibido conducir fuera de las carreteras asfaltadas .
Casi 20 muertes por quemaduras en fuentes termales se reportan en Yellowstone desde 1872. (REUTERS/Jim Urquhart) Wolfley , al ser localizado, dijo que ‚Äúlas multas eran bastante excesivas y el castigo bastante extremo‚Äù. Los intentos de contactar con Flaherty por tel√©fono y correo electr√≥nico no tuvieron √©xito.
Las autoridades de Wyoming citaron casos similares como advertencia a los turistas. El a√±o pasado, un turista fue condenado a una semana de c√°rcel por ignorar las se√±alizaciones que dec√≠an que era ilegal salir de la zona del camino establecido.
En 2024, el actor Pierce Brosnan , quien camin√≥ por una zona termal, fue condenado a pagar una multa de 500 d√≥lares y a hacer un donativo de 1000 d√≥lares a Yellowstone Forever , una organizaci√≥n sin fines de lucro asociada al parque.
Casi dos decenas de personas han muerto por quemaduras sufridas tras entrar o caer en una fuente termal de Yellowstone desde que se inaugur√≥ el parque en 1872, seg√∫n el Servicio Geol√≥gico de Estados Unidos .
